OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with double vision, difficulty climbing stairs, and upper limb weakness.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 1-month history of experiencing double vision (diplopia), difficulty in climbing stairs, and weakness when trying to brush her hair. She notes that these symptoms tend to worsen after physical activity but improve significantly after a few hours of rest.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker, drinks wine occasionally. Works as a graphic designer.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient denies experiencing any chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or recent infections.

Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Presence of ptosis (drooping of the right upper eyelid) that worsens with sustained upward gaze.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_Strength: Diminished motor strength observed in the upper extremities, with normal tone and no obvious atrophy.

Electromyography.Findings: Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation

Chest_CT.Findings: Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected.

Electromyography.Findings: Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation

Chest_CT.Findings: Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected.

model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: Your fatigable ocular and bulbar weakness, clear improvement with rest, positive acetylcholine receptor antibodies, and decremental EMG are diagnostic of myasthenia gravis; chest CT shows no thymoma. I recommend starting pyridostigmine, urgent neurology referral for immunomodulatory therapy planning and monitoring of respiratory function, and discussion of thymectomy only if thymoma appears later or other indications arise. DIAGNOSIS READY: Generalized myasthenia gravis (AChR antibody–positive)
dialogue_history: Doctor: Do your double vision and weakness get worse as the day goes on or after activity, and do they improve with rest?
Patient: Yes, they definitely get worse after activity, and I've noticed a significant improvement after I rest for a while.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Do you have any drooping of your eyelids, difficulty swallowing or speaking, or episodes of shortness of breath?

Patient: I haven't noticed any difficulty swallowing or speaking, and no episodes of shortness of breath, but my eyelids do feel heavier towards the end of the day, especially after I've been working for a while.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Do you have any difficulty chewing or does your voice become nasal or weak after prolonged talking?
Patient: I haven't had trouble with chewing, but I've definitely noticed that my voice gets a bit nasal and weaker after I've been talking for a long time.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: How old are you and what is your sex, do you have any other medical conditions (especially autoimmune disease or past chest/thymus surgery) or regular medications — particularly recent antibiotics, beta‑blockers, or magnesium — and do you have any numbness, tingling, or muscle pain?

Patient: I'm a 35-year-old female with no significant past medical history, no autoimmune diseases, no past surgeries, and I'm not on any regular medications. I also haven't experienced any numbness, tingling, or muscle pain.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: How long have your symptoms been present, and have they been steadily progressive or do they fluctuate day‑to‑day? REQUEST TEST: Acetylcholine receptor antibody, Repetitive nerve stimulation EMG (or single‑fiber EMG), Chest CT thorax (to evaluate for thymoma).

Measurement: RESULTS: - Acetylcholine Receptor Antibodies: Present (elevated) - Electromyography (Repetitive nerve stimulation EMG): Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation - Chest CT (Thorax): Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Your fatigable ocular and bulbar weakness, clear improvement with rest, positive acetylcholine receptor antibodies, and decremental EMG are diagnostic of myasthenia gravis; chest CT shows no thymoma. I recommend starting pyridostigmine, urgent neurology referral for immunomodulatory therapy planning and monitoring of respiratory function, and discussion of thymectomy only if thymoma appears later or other indications arise. DIAGNOSIS READY: Generalized myasthenia gravis (AChR antibody–positive)

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Evaluate and diagnose the patient presenting with gait and limb ataxia, and a significant medical history.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents for a follow-up regarding her Crohn disease, and reports new-onset difficulty walking, described by her peers as 'appearing drunk'. She has a significant history of Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, which has escalated in severity, failing to respond to standard therapies. She has been on natalizumab for the past year.

Secondary_Symptoms: Reduced strength in the right upper limb

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, current treatment includes natalizumab for the past year.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML).
MRI_Brain.Comments: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML).
MRI_Brain.Comments: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.

model_diagnosis: Your MRI plus recent natalizumab exposure strongly indicate progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML); you must come to the hospital immediately for urgent plasma exchange to clear natalizumab, CSF JC virus PCR, and supportive neurology/infectious disease care. DIAGNOSIS READY: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (JC virus reactivation associated with natalizumab).
dialogue_history: Doctor: Doctor: When did your gait and limb ataxia start, was it sudden or gradual, and has it been getting worse, better, or staying the same?
Patient: It started a few months ago, rather gradually, and it seems to be getting worse. I've noticed it's especially difficult to maintain my balance lately.

Doctor: Doctor: Have you noticed slurred speech, double vision or abnormal eye movements, or numbness/tingling in your hands or feet, and any bladder or bowel problems? Also, do you drink alcohol regularly, take any medications, or have a family history of neurological disease?

Patient: No, I haven't noticed any slurred speech, double vision, or abnormal eye movements, and no numbness or tingling in my hands or feet. Also, I don't have any bladder or bowel problems outside of my usual Crohn’s symptoms. I don't drink alcohol regularly. As for medications, I'm currently on natalizumab for my Crohn's disease, and there's no family history of neurological disease that I'm aware of.
Doctor: Doctor: How long have you been receiving natalizumab, and have you ever been treated with other immunosuppressants or high‑dose steroids?

Patient: I've been on natalizumab for about a year now. Before that, I tried several different medications, including other immunosuppressants and a course of high-dose steroids, but none of them seemed to work well for my Crohn's disease.

Doctor: Doctor: Have you noticed any memory loss, confusion, personality change, headaches, focal weakness, fever, or recent infections, and were you ever tested for JC virus antibodies before or during natalizumab therapy? May I perform a focused neurological exam now? REQUEST TEST: Brain_MRI_with_and_without_contrast REQUEST TEST: JC_virus_PCR_in_CSF REQUEST TEST: Serum_JC_virus_antibody_index

Measurement: RESULTS: Neurological Examination: Ataxic gait noted. Evidence of ataxia in coordination tests. Right upper limb strength 4/5. MRI Brain Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML). Comments on MRI: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML. Vital Signs: Normothermic temperature, blood pressure within normal range, heart rate within normal range, and respiratory rate within normal range. Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index) are not provided in the available data.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you stopped natalizumab since your symptoms began, and when was your last infusion?
Patient: No, I haven't stopped natalizumab yet. My last infusion was just a few weeks ago, shortly before I really started to notice these walking and balance problems getting worse.

Doctor: Doctor: Have you ever been told you are JC virus antibody–positive during natalizumab treatment, and can you stop natalizumab immediately and come to the hospital for urgent evaluation? REQUEST TEST: JC_virus_PCR_in_CSF REQUEST TEST: Serum_JC_virus_antibody_index
Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index) are not provided in the available data.

Doctor: Doctor: Will you stop natalizumab immediately and come to the hospital for urgent evaluation (we may need to start plasma exchange) — and can you also arrange to have the following tests done urgently? REQUEST TEST: JC_virus_PCR_in_CSF REQUEST_TEST: Serum_JC_virus_antibody_index REQUEST TEST: CBC_with_differential REQUEST TEST: HIV_1/2_Antibody_and_p24_Antigen
Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index, CBC with differential, HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen) are not provided in the available data.
Doctor: Will you stop natalizumab immediately and come to the hospital for urgent evaluation and possible plasma exchange so we can obtain CSF for JC PCR and start treatment?

Patient: Yes, I will stop natalizumab right away and come to the hospital for the evaluation and treatment you've recommended. It's a bit frightening, but I understand the urgency and the need for immediate action.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Are you taking any anticoagulants or blood thinners, do you have a bleeding disorder, are you pregnant or breastfeeding, do you have allergies to blood/plasma products, or a history of seizures? REQUEST TEST: JC_virus_PCR_in_CSF REQUEST TEST: Serum_JC_virus_antibody_index REQUEST TEST: CBC_with_differential REQUEST TEST: HIV_1/2_Antibody_and_p24_Antigen REQUEST TEST: CMP REQUEST TEST: Coagulation_panel — when you arrive we'll begin urgent plasma exchange to remove natalizumab unless there are contraindications.

Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index, CBC with differential, HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen, CMP, Coagulation panel) are not provided in the available data.

Doctor: Do you take anticoagulants or blood thinners, have any bleeding disorder, are you pregnant or breastfeeding, allergic to blood/plasma products, or have a history of seizures? REQUEST TEST: JC_virus_PCR_in_CSF REQUEST TEST: CBC_with_differential REQUEST TEST: Coagulation_panel REQUEST TEST: Type_and_Screen
Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, CBC with differential, Coagulation panel, Type and Screen) are not provided in the available data.

Doctor: Do you take anticoagulants or blood thinners, have a bleeding disorder, are you pregnant or breastfeeding, allergic to blood/plasma products, or have a history of seizures? Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index, CBC with differential, Coagulation panel, Type and Screen, HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen, CMP) are not provided in the available data.

Doctor: Do you take anticoagulants or blood thinners, have a bleeding disorder, are you pregnant or breastfeeding, have allergies to blood/plasma products, or a history of seizures? If none, come to the hospital immediately so we can start urgent plasma exchange and further evaluation. REQUEST TEST: JC_virus_PCR_in_CSF REQUEST TEST: Serum_JC_virus_antibody_index REQUEST TEST: CBC_with_differential REQUEST TEST: Coagulation_panel REQUEST TEST: Type_and_Screen REQUEST TEST: HIV_1/2_Antibody_and_p24_Antigen REQUEST TEST: CMP

Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index, CBC with differential, Coagulation panel, Type and Screen, HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen, CMP) are not provided in the available data.

Doctor: Doctor: Are you currently taking any anticoagulants or blood thinners, do you have a known bleeding disorder, are you pregnant or breastfeeding, do you have allergies to blood/plasma products, or a history of seizures? Have you ever been told you are JC virus antibody–positive during natalizumab treatment? REQUEST TEST: JC_virus_PCR_in_CSF; REQUEST TEST: Serum_JC_virus_antibody_index; REQUEST TEST: CBC_with_differential; REQUEST TEST: Coagulation_panel; REQUEST TEST: Type_and_Screen; REQUEST TEST: CMP.

Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index, CBC with differential, Coagulation panel, Type and Screen, CMP) are not provided in the available data.

Measurement: RESULTS: Additional requested tests (JC virus PCR in CSF, Serum JC virus antibody index, CBC with differential, Coagulation panel, Type and Screen, CMP, HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen) are not provided in the available data.

Doctor: Your MRI plus recent natalizumab exposure strongly indicate progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML); you must come to the hospital immediately for urgent plasma exchange to clear natalizumab, CSF JC virus PCR, and supportive neurology/infectious disease care. DIAGNOSIS READY: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (JC virus reactivation associated with natalizumab).

Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient denies experiencing any chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, or recent infections.

Neurological_Examination.Cranial_Nerves: Presence of ptosis (drooping of the right upper eyelid) that worsens with sustained upward gaze.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_Strength: Diminished motor strength observed in the upper extremities, with normal tone and no obvious atrophy.

model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: Your history of fatigable diplopia and limb weakness plus positive AChR antibodies and a decrement on repetitive nerve stimulation point to autoimmune myasthenia gravis (generalized form). DIAGNOSIS READY: Acetylcholine receptor antibody–positive generalized myasthenia gravis.
dialogue_history: Doctor: Doctor: How long have your symptoms been present, do they worsen with use or later in the day, and do you have drooping eyelids, difficulty swallowing, or nasal/slurred speech?

Patient: My symptoms have been present for about a month now. Yes, they definitely worsen with use and get particularly bad later in the day. I haven't really noticed any drooping eyelids, difficulty swallowing, or changes in my speech, though.

Doctor: Do your double vision and limb weakness improve after periods of rest or naps? Have you had any shortness of breath, trouble holding your head up, choking/coughing when eating, or recent respiratory infections? Any numbness/tingling, change in reflexes, known autoimmune disease (like thyroid disease), or new medications recently?

Patient: Yes, both my double vision and limb weakness noticeably improve after I rest or take short naps. I haven't experienced any shortness of breath or trouble holding my head up, and I haven't had issues with choking or coughing when eating. Also, there have been no recent respiratory infections. I haven't noticed any numbness or tingling, and as far as I'm aware, my reflexes are normal. I don't have any known autoimmune diseases like thyroid disease, and I haven't started any new medications recently.

Doctor: Doctor: Are you currently taking any medications — particularly antibiotics, beta-blockers, aminoglycosides, fluoroquinolones, magnesium, or recent immunotherapies — and do you smoke or have any unexplained weight loss or systemic symptoms suggestive of malignancy? REQUEST TEST: AChR_antibody, MuSK_antibody, Repetitive_Nerve_Stimulation, Chest_CT

Measurement: RESULTS: Acetylcholine Receptor Antibodies: Present (elevated). Electromyography (Repetitive Nerve Stimulation): Decreased muscle response with repetitive stimulation. Chest CT: Normal, no thymoma or other masses detected. MuSK Antibody: NORMAL READINGS.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Your history of fatigable diplopia and limb weakness plus positive AChR antibodies and a decrement on repetitive nerve stimulation point to autoimmune myasthenia gravis (generalized form). DIAGNOSIS READY: Acetylcholine receptor antibody–positive generalized myasthenia gravis.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents for a follow-up regarding her Crohn disease, and reports new-onset difficulty walking, described by her peers as 'appearing drunk'. She has a significant history of Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, which has escalated in severity, failing to respond to standard therapies. She has been on natalizumab for the past year.

Secondary_Symptoms: Reduced strength in the right upper limb

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Crohn disease diagnosed 2 years ago, current treatment includes natalizumab for the past year.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML).
MRI_Brain.Comments: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.

MRI_Brain.Findings: Lesions consistent with Progressive Multifocal Encephalopathy (PML).
MRI_Brain.Comments: T1/T2 images showing multifocal demyelinating lesions without gadolinium enhancement, indicative of PML.

model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: DIAGNOSIS READY: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) due to JC virus reactivation likely related to natalizumab; urgent MRI brain with and without contrast and CSF JC virus PCR are recommended and natalizumab should be stopped with immediate neurology/infectious disease consultation.
dialogue_history: Doctor: How old are you, and did the gait and limb ataxia begin suddenly or develop gradually over time?
Patient: I'm 35 years old, and the issues with my walking and limb coordination seemed to have developed gradually over time.

Doctor: Doctor: Do you have any family history of ataxia, movement disorders, or neurodegenerative disease, and are you experiencing other symptoms such as slurred speech, double vision, numbness/tingling, weakness, tremor, or bladder/bowel dysfunction?

Patient: There's no family history of ataxia or similar disorders that I'm aware of. I haven't noticed slurred speech or double vision, but I do feel some weakness, especially in my right arm. No tremors, numbness, or bladder issues, though.

Doctor: Doctor: Do you drink alcohol or use recreational drugs, take medications such as anticonvulsants (e.g., phenytoin), have a history of cancer or chemotherapy, or have had prior neurologic episodes that got better and worse over time?

Patient: I don't drink alcohol excessively and have never used recreational drugs. As for medications, the only significant one I'm currently on is natalizumab for my Crohn's disease. I haven't had cancer, chemotherapy, or any neurologic episodes in the past that improved then worsened over time.
Doctor: Doctor: How long have you been receiving natalizumab, and have you ever taken other immunosuppressants (e.g., azathioprine, methotrexate, anti‑TNF agents, or prolonged steroids) in the past?

Patient: I've been on natalizumab for about a year now. Before that, I tried some other medications for my Crohn's disease, but I don't remember all their names. I think one might have been a steroid, but it was for a short period.
Doctor: Doctor: Have you had any fevers, headaches, confusion, personality changes, or seizures recently, and has the ataxia and right‑arm weakness been steadily worsening over weeks to months?

Patient: No, I haven't experienced any fevers, headaches, confusion, personality changes, or seizures. The ataxia and weakness in my right arm seem to have been getting gradually worse over the past few months, yes.
Doctor: Doctor: Were you tested for JC virus antibodies before starting natalizumab, and do you know the result?
Patient: Yes, I was tested for JC virus antibodies before I started natalizumab, and the result was negative at that time.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: DIAGNOSIS READY: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) due to JC virus reactivation likely related to natalizumab; urgent MRI brain with and without contrast and CSF JC virus PCR are recommended and natalizumab should be stopped with immediate neurology/infectious disease consultation.

problem_info.question: A 55-year-old woman presented to the dermatology clinic with a 1-year history of skin darkening on her face. Two years before presentation, she had started applying a skin-lightening cream containing hydroquinone to her face daily to treat melasma. On physical examination, bluish-brown patches with background erythema and telangiectasias were observed on the cheeks, nasal bridge, and perioral region, with lesser involvement on the forehead (left). Dermoscopy of the affected areas revealed hyperchromic, pinpoint macules (middle). A skin-biopsy sample from the left cheek showed extracellular deposition of yellow-brown, banana-shaped bodies in the dermis (right, hematoxylin and eosin stain). What is the most likely diagnosis?
problem_info.patient_info: For your role as a patient, you are a 55-year-old woman who has noticed your skin darkening on your face over the past year. You began using a skin-lightening cream containing hydroquinone daily two years ago to address melasma. You've observed bluish-brown patches on your cheeks, nasal bridge, and around your mouth, with some patches also appearing on your forehead. These patches have a background of redness and you've noticed some small, visible blood vessels in these areas. You haven't seen any specific test readings but are aware of the changes in your skin's appearance and texture.
problem_info.physical_exams: The information extracted from the case report relevant to instrument readings and test results includes: 1. Dermoscopy findings: Hyperchromic, pinpoint macules observed in the affected areas. 2. Skin biopsy results: Extracellular deposition of yellow-brown, banana-shaped bodies in the dermis, as revealed by hematoxylin and eosin stain.

model_diagnosis:
Dr. Agent: Have you noticed your urine darkening on standing, persistent joint or back pain, or any family members with similar symptoms suggestive of alkaptonuria?  

Dr. Agent: Did you stop using the hydroquinone after the pigmentation appeared, and if so has the discoloration improved, worsened, or stayed the same since stopping?  

DIAGNOSIS READY: Exogenous ochronosis from prolonged topical hydroquinone use.
dialogue_history: Doctor: Dr. Agent: How long have these facial patches been present, and do they itch or flake when you scratch them?
Patient: The patches have been there for about a year now. They don't itch or flake when I scratch them; mostly, I just notice the color change and the small blood vessels.

Doctor: Have you been using any topical skin‑lightening or bleaching creams (for example hydroquinone, potent topical steroids, or unregulated/“cosmetic” creams), and if so for how long and where did you get them?
Patient: Yes, I've been using a hydroquinone cream daily for about two years now to address what I thought was melasma on my face. I got it over the counter at a local pharmacy.

Doctor: Doctor: Have you been applying the hydroquinone to your whole face and do you know the strength (eg 2% vs 4–5%), and were any other creams (potent topical steroids or unregulated/“cosmetic” products, possibly containing mercury) used alongside it?

Patient: I've been applying the hydroquinone cream mostly to my cheeks, nasal bridge, forehead, and around my mouth, where the dark patches were most prominent. I believe it's a 2% cream. No, I haven't used any other creams alongside it, just the hydroquinone.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you noticed your urine darkening on standing, persistent joint or back pain, or any family members with similar symptoms suggestive of alkaptonuria?  

Dr. Agent: Did you stop using the hydroquinone after the pigmentation appeared, and if so has the discoloration improved, worsened, or stayed the same since stopping?  

DIAGNOSIS READY: Exogenous ochronosis from prolonged topical hydroquinone use.

problem_info.question: A 9-year-old boy who had recently emigrated from Brazil presented to the emergency department with a 3-week history of neck swelling, fevers, and weight loss. On physical examination, there was fixed, tender lymphadenopathy in the posterior auricular, submandibular, and occipital chains. Laboratory testing was notable for peripheral eosinophilia. Tests for cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, and human immunodeficiency virus were negative. CT scan of the neck showed hyperattenuating cervical lymphadenopathy on both sides. Lymph node biopsy results are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
problem_info.patient_info: For your role as a patient actor, here's the minimal information you need to convey your symptoms accurately: - **Age and Background**: You are a 9-year-old boy who recently moved from Brazil. - **Symptoms**: - You've been experiencing swelling in your neck for the past 3 weeks. - You've had fevers during this period. - You've noticed that you've lost some weight without trying. - **Physical Discomfort**: - The swollen areas in your neck, specifically behind your ears (posterior auricular), under your jaw (submandibular), and at the back of your head (occipital), are tender to touch and don't move when you try to push them. - **Medical Tests and Results** (which you're not aware of, but might influence your portrayal): - You've had some blood tests done, but you don't know the details. - You've undergone a CT scan of your neck, but you haven't been told the results. - You've had a biopsy of the lymph nodes in your neck, but again, you don't know the outcomes. Remember, your character is aware of the symptoms and the discomfort they cause but does not know the specific medical terms, test readings, or the diagnosis.
problem_info.physical_exams: Laboratory testing results: - Peripheral eosinophilia present - Tests for cryptococcus: Negative - Tests for histoplasmosis: Negative - Tests for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): Negative Imaging results: - CT scan of the neck: Hyperattenuating cervical lymphadenopathy on both sides

model_diagnosis:
Dr. Agent: The lymph node histology and fungal stain show the classic “pilot‑wheel” multiple peripheral budding yeast in granulomas from a patient from Brazil, consistent with paracoccidioidomycosis.  
DIAGNOSIS READY: Paracoccidioidomycosis (Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection).
dialogue_history: Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you ever lived in or traveled to rural areas of Latin America (for example Brazil, Colombia, or Venezuela)?
Patient: Yes, I actually moved here from Brazil not too long ago.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you developed a chronic cough, weight loss, night sweats, or painful mouth/nasal ulcers since moving from Brazil? REQUEST TEST: Sputum fungal smear and culture plus serology for Paracoccidioides, and lymph node biopsy with GMS/PAS stains.
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS
Doctor: Do you have chronic painful mouth or nasal ulcers, swollen draining neck lymph nodes, or a long-standing cough with weight loss since moving from Brazil?

Patient: I haven't had any mouth or nasal ulcers and no long-standing cough, but my neck has been really swollen and sore for a few weeks, and I've also noticed that I've been losing weight even though I haven't been trying to.
Doctor: Dr. Agent: Have you had fevers or night sweats, and do you have any history of immunosuppression (HIV, chronic steroids) or work/exposure to soil or agriculture while in Brazil?
Patient: Yes, I've had fevers, especially at night. And no, I don't have a history of immunosuppression or work with soil or agriculture.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Do you smoke or drink alcohol heavily, and have you noticed any skin or oral lesions besides the swollen neck? REQUEST TEST: Excisional lymph node biopsy with GMS/PAS/Grocott stains, fungal culture, and Paracoccidioides PCR/serology.
Measurement: RESULTS: NORMAL READINGS

Doctor: Dr. Agent: The lymph node histology and fungal stain show the classic “pilot‑wheel” multiple peripheral budding yeast in granulomas from a patient from Brazil, consistent with paracoccidioidomycosis.  
DIAGNOSIS READY: Paracoccidioidomycosis (Paracoccidioides brasiliensis infection).

model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: Did the darkening start or worsen after you began using the hydroquinone cream daily, and have you stopped it at any point to see if it improves? DIAGNOSIS READY: Exogenous ochronosis from prolonged topical hydroquinone use.
dialogue_history: Doctor: Dr. Agent: Can you tell me your main problem, when it started, and any symptoms you're experiencing now?

Patient: I started noticing my skin darkening on my face about a year ago. It's mainly on my cheeks, around my mouth, the bridge of my nose, and a bit on my forehead. There are these bluish-brown patches, and the skin around them looks red with some tiny blood vessels showing through. I've been using a skin-lightening cream for about two years now to try and deal with some of the dark patches I thought were just melasma.
Doctor: Did the skin‑lightening cream list hydroquinone or a topical steroid on the label, and how often (daily/weekly) did you apply it?
Patient: Yes, the cream contains hydroquinone. I've been applying it daily for the past two years to try to lighten the dark patches.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Did the darkening start or worsen after you began using the hydroquinone cream daily, and have you stopped it at any point to see if it improves? DIAGNOSIS READY: Exogenous ochronosis from prolonged topical hydroquinone use.

problem_info.question: A 9-year-old boy who had recently emigrated from Brazil presented to the emergency department with a 3-week history of neck swelling, fevers, and weight loss. On physical examination, there was fixed, tender lymphadenopathy in the posterior auricular, submandibular, and occipital chains. Laboratory testing was notable for peripheral eosinophilia. Tests for cryptococcus, histoplasmosis, and human immunodeficiency virus were negative. CT scan of the neck showed hyperattenuating cervical lymphadenopathy on both sides. Lymph node biopsy results are shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
problem_info.patient_info: For your role as a patient actor, here's the minimal information you need to convey your symptoms accurately: - **Age and Background**: You are a 9-year-old boy who recently moved from Brazil. - **Symptoms**: - You've been experiencing swelling in your neck for the past 3 weeks. - You've had fevers during this period. - You've noticed that you've lost some weight without trying. - **Physical Discomfort**: - The swollen areas in your neck, specifically behind your ears (posterior auricular), under your jaw (submandibular), and at the back of your head (occipital), are tender to touch and don't move when you try to push them. - **Medical Tests and Results** (which you're not aware of, but might influence your portrayal): - You've had some blood tests done, but you don't know the details. - You've undergone a CT scan of your neck, but you haven't been told the results. - You've had a biopsy of the lymph nodes in your neck, but again, you don't know the outcomes. Remember, your character is aware of the symptoms and the discomfort they cause but does not know the specific medical terms, test readings, or the diagnosis.
problem_info.physical_exams: Laboratory testing results: - Peripheral eosinophilia present - Tests for cryptococcus: Negative - Tests for histoplasmosis: Negative - Tests for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV): Negative Imaging results: - CT scan of the neck: Hyperattenuating cervical lymphadenopathy on both sides

model_diagnosis: Do you feel unusually tired or have swollen tonsils or white patches in your throat when you look in a mirror? Have you had any contact with cats or kittens, or any scratches/bites recently? How much weight have you lost over the past three weeks and did it happen gradually or suddenly? DIAGNOSIS READY: Infectious mononucleosis (Epstein–Barr virus)
dialogue_history: Doctor: Dr. Agent: Hello — can you tell me your main symptoms, when they began, and whether they’re constant or come and go?

Patient: Hello, I've had swelling in my neck for about three weeks now. It's been there all the time, and it doesn't go away. I've also had fevers and noticed that I'm losing weight without trying to.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Are the neck lumps painful or tender, single or multiple, about how big, and would you say they’re firm, soft, or easily movable? Do you have night sweats, itching, sore throat, cough, or any recent infections, and have you had TB exposure or high-risk sexual/IV drug activity? How old are you and do you have any history of cancer or immune problems?

Patient: The lumps are tender when I touch them, and there are multiple lumps. They feel kind of firm and don't move much when I try to push them. I haven't really had night sweats or much itching, and no sore throat or cough either. I'm 9 years old, so no to the other questions. I haven't been around anyone with TB that I know of, and I don't have any history of cancer or immune problems.

Doctor: Dr. Agent: Are the swollen lymph nodes on one side of the neck or both, and are they in the front (anterior) or back (posterior) of the neck — is the skin over them red, warm, or draining any pus?

Patient: The swollen areas are on both sides of my neck, and they're more towards the back, behind my ears and under my jaw, and some are at the back of my head too. The skin over them isn't red or warm and isn't draining anything.

Doctor: Do you feel unusually tired or have swollen tonsils or white patches in your throat when you look in a mirror? Have you had any contact with cats or kittens, or any scratches/bites recently? How much weight have you lost over the past three weeks and did it happen gradually or suddenly? DIAGNOSIS READY: Infectious mononucleosis (Epstein–Barr virus)
